questions.questionText: Describe the difference between a stack and a queue. Provide one common use-case for each.
questions.correctAnswer: A stack follows the Last-In-First-Out (LIFO) principle where the last element added is removed first. A queue follows the First-In-First-Out (FIFO) principle where the first element added is removed first. Stacks are commonly used for function call management and undo operations; queues are used for scheduling tasks and order processing.
questions.explanation: Stacks operate with two main operations: push and pop, and are crucial for recursive function stacks, browser history, etc. Queues operate with enqueue and dequeue, essential in resource scheduling and breadth-first search.
questions.codeExample:
// Stack (Kotlin)
val stack = Stack<Int>()
stack.push(1)
stack.pop()
// Queue (Kotlin)
val queue: Queue<Int> = LinkedList()
queue.add(1)
queue.poll()
